doc.field: Fischer points out consequences for national politics

After the decision of the North Rhine-Westphalian Greens to continue the coalition with the Social Democratic Party (SPD), the Parliamentary Party Leader of the Greens has pointed out the consequences on the federal level. Mr Fischer warned the SPD on the "ARD" TV station that the national election at the end of September will be a decision about a new energy policy. He said that the Greens could not support using brown coal as fuel for electricity. North Rhine-Westphalia's State Premier Rau stressed that the SPD will continue to support the mining of brown coal. In spite of disagreement in this matter, the North Rhine-Westphalian Green Party decided yesterday during a special party convention to continue the coalition with the SPD.
Schaeuble against grand coalition on federal level

The Parliamentary Leader of the Union Parties in the Bundestag, Mr. Schaeuble, has revised earlier statements and now opposes a grand coalition (CDU/CSU and SPD). On the "Deutschlandfunk" radio station, Mr. Schaeuble rejected even a short-term collaboration to solve pressing national problems. He said that the present governing coalition has to instead fight for victory in the coming state parliament elections to break the SPD's majority in the Bundesrat [upper house of parliament] before the Bundestag [lower house of parliament] elections in September. A week ago, Mr. Schaeuble had not excluded a grand coalition in an interview with the magazine "Spiegel". He said that in the September election, the Union's goal is to attract more than 40 percent of the votes. Union parties have to fight for themselves to reach that goal and that they Union cannot give away any votes.
PDS plans to support Lafontaine

The Party of Democratic Socialism (PDS) has announced their support of Oskar Lafontaine, the head of the SPD, to avoid a grand coalition after the Bundestag election. Gregor Gysi, the Speaker of the PDS fraction, said, if Mr. Lafontaine needs his party's support and prefers a minority government to a grand coalition, the PDS would cooperate. But Mr. Gysi however rejects supporting the State Premier of Lower Saxony Gerhard Schroeder in the election for Chancellor. He said that the PDS only supports a reform government, which, in his opinion, is impossible with Mr. Schroeder.
Kick-off of election campaign in Lower Saxony

The SPD has started their important phase of the state parliament elections in Lower Saxony with a big event. SPD President Oskar Lafontaine and State Premier Gerhard Schroeder participated in the opening ceremony. Rudolf Scharping, the Parliamentary Group Leader of the Social Democrats in the Bundestag, was expected in Hannover as well. The result of the election on March 1 is viewed as a decision about who is going to be the SPD's candidate for Chancellor. Gerhard Schroeder wants to abstain from running for Chancellor if he receives 2 percent fewer votes in Lower Saxony than in 1994.
Troge wants to raise mineral oil tax by 50 pfennigs

The President of the Federal Department for the Environment Troge has pleaded that mineral oil tax be raised by 50 pfennigs per litre on a medium-term basis. Mr. Troge explained his model to the paper "Berliner Tagesspiegel". He said that after a preparatory phase of two years, during which citizens have time to get used to the idea, the price for gas and diesel will be raised by 10 pfennigs each year. The President of the Department for the Environment has rejected the Green's demands to increase the price of gas to 5 marks.
Warning against tightening non-smoker protection laws

Mr. Scholz, the legal expert of the Christian Democratic Union (CDU), has warned against tightening non-smoker protection laws. He referred to plans to punish violations of non-smoker protection laws with 5000 mark fines. Mr. Scholz told the weekly paper "Bild am Sonntag" that the goal should be an efficient government with less bureaucracy and laws. Militant non-smokers' plans have exactly the opposite effect. Mr. Lutz, the President of the Police Union, agrees with this and said that the police have more important things to do than to deal with illegal smokers.
Police break up right-wing event

In Pirma, Saxony, police broke up an unauthorised event of right-wing teenagers. About 450 members of the right-wing scene had gathered for a concert in a club house. Police confiscated propaganda material and music cassettes. In Wittstock, Brandenburg, police arrested eleven teenagers who had shouted Nazi slogans in front of a restaurant. The group is said to have caused riots earlier in the inner city .
Renewed attacks against punks

Another punk has been attacked and seriously injured in Magdeburg. Police today reported that a 21-year-old has been shot in the face with a gas pistol. Both eyes of the young man were injured. The attacker escaped unidentified.
Waigel asked to abandon tax on cultural sponsoring

Representatives of cultural groups and industry have called on Theo Waigel, the German Minister of Finance, to revoke the recently introduced tax on cultural sponsoring. If institutions have to pay half of donations received in taxes, venues such as museums, theatre and concert halls will no longer be supported, warned the Professional Organisations of Actors, Musicians and Museums as well as the Goethe Institute and the Federation of German Industry. The President of the Actors' Association August Everding told the paper "Frankfurter Allgemeine Sonntagszeitung" that cultural institutions need support to realise projects which the government cannot, or does not, want to fund.
Katja Seizinger comes second

Katja Seizinger of SC Halblech came second in the world cup championships in Altenmarkt/Zauchensee. She lost first place to the Austrian Renate Goetschel. Alexandra Meissnitzer, also from Austria, came third.
Jan Hempel wins bronze, Sandra Voelker and Ralf Braun win silver

Jan Hempel, the European champion from Dresden, has won a bronze medal for diving at the World Swimming Championships in Perth, Australia. Dimitri Santin of Russia won gold, Jang Tian of China won silver. Sandra Voelker from Hamburg won silver in the 50m crawl. The American Amy van Dyken became the world champion. Ralf Braun from Berlin also won silver in the 200 m backstroke; Lenny Krazelberg of America won gold.
Double German victory in speed skating
The German team has won a double victory at the Speed Skating World Championships in Innsbruck - Gunda Niemann-Stirnemann came first, while Anni Friesinger came second.
